text: The need for time zones arose with the expansion of global trade and transportation networks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Before the advent of standardized time measurement, communities used local solar time based on the position of the sun in the sky.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This worked well for localized activities but posed challenges as transportation and communication capabilities improved.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Trains and telegraphs, in particular, highlighted the inefficiencies of using local time across long distances.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first major development in timekeeping came with the introduction of standard time in the mid-19th century.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Before this, each town or city would set its own time based on the local position of the sun.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: However, this system became increasingly impractical as rail travel became more widespread.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In 1847, the British railway companies adopted a single standard time for their schedules, known as Railway Time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This marked the beginning of standardized timekeeping on a regional level.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The concept of time zones as we know them today was first proposed by Sir Sandford Fleming, a Canadian engineer, in the late 19th century.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Fleming suggested dividing the world into 24 time zones, each one representing a one-hour difference in mean solar time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This idea gained traction at the International Meridian Conference held in Washington, D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in 1884, where it was agreed to adopt a system of standard time zones based on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The Greenwich Meridian, located in London, was chosen as the Prime Meridian from which all time zones would be calculated.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This decision established GMT as the reference point for coordinating time across the globe.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The conference also divided the world into 24 time zones, each spanning 15 degrees of longitude.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This system allowed for a more precise and standardized way of measuring time, facilitating global communication and coordination.

text: Following the adoption of standard time zones at the International Meridian Conference, countries around the world began to implement the new system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The United States, for example, divided the country into four time zones: Eastern, Central, Mountain, and Pacific.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Other countries followed suit, adjusting their timekeeping practices to align with the new standard.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The development of time zones was further refined with the introduction of Daylight Saving Time (DST) in the early 20th century.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: DST is the practice of advancing clocks by one hour during the warmer months to extend daylight hours in the evening.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This was first implemented during World War I as a way to conserve energy and make better use of natural daylight.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: DST has since become a common practice in many countries, with the dates of the time changes varying depending on local regulations.
